title: AHA Scientific Statement 2023: Cognitive Impairment After Ischemic and Hemorrhagic Stroke

recommendations.text: PSCI risk is higher with lobar ICH (often CAA-related), SAH complications, larger lesion burden, and markers such as WMH or atrophy.
MoCA is generally preferred over MMSE for poststroke cognitive screening; tool choice should reflect demographics, culture, language, and stroke deficits.
Use tailored neuropsychological evaluation when screening is inadequate or when deficits are complex or subtle.
Screen when there is cognitive complaint or clinician concern and plan longitudinal reassessment; avoid mislabeling from cultural or language bias.
Aggressively manage vascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, lipids, smoking, sleep apnea) to reduce recurrent stroke and PSCI risk.
Simultaneous control of multiple vascular risks may slow cognitive decline compared with single-risk interventions.
Acute reperfusion therapies may improve cognitive outcomes by reducing infarct size, although evidence is limited and heterogeneous.
Cholinesterase inhibitors or memantine can yield small cognitive benefits but may cause adverse effects; use selectively.
Emerging therapies (tDCS, rTMS, remote ischemic conditioning, acupuncture) show preliminary benefit; confirmatory studies are needed.
Provide interdisciplinary care and address comorbid depression, sleep disorders, and social supports that influence cognitive recovery.
